revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2008 |Team=Iowa Hawkeyes |Image= Iowa logo.jpg |ImageSize= |Conference=Big Ten Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big Ten |CoachRank=20 |APRank=20 |Record=9â4 |ConfRecord=5â3 |HeadCoach=[[Kirk Ferentz]]{{cite web|title = Kirk Ferentz|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/ferentz_kirk00.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-16}} |OffCoach=[[Ken O'Keefe]] |DefCoach=Norm Parker |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Kinnick Stadium]]
Capacity: 70,585{{cite web|title = Kinnick Stadium|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/facilities/iowa-kinnick-stadium.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-10-12}} |Champion=Outback Bowl Champions |BowlTourney= [[2009 Outback Bowl|Outback Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult=W 31-10 vs. [[2008 South Carolina Gamecocks football team|South Carolina]] |uniform=File:BigTen-Uniform-Iowa-2006-2008.png }} {{2008 Big Ten football standings}} The '''2008 Iowa Hawkeyes football team''' represented the [[University of Iowa]] and the [[Iowa Hawkeyes football]] program in the [[2008 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2008 college football season]]. Coached by [[Kirk Ferentz]], the Hawkeyes played their seven home games in [[Kinnick Stadium]]. ==Leading up to the season== ===Previous season=== {{main|2007 Iowa Hawkeyes football team}} [[File:Iowa vs. Syracuse 2007.jpg|thumb|right|Iowa's defense lines up against the [[Syracuse Orange#Football history|Syracuse Orange]] on September 8, 2007.]] Iowa opened the 2007 season on September 1, 2007, against [[Northern Illinois Huskies|Northern Illinois]] in a game played at [[Soldier Field]] in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. Hawkeye [[running back]]s Albert Young and Damian Sims ran for 144 and 110 yards rushing respectively, while Iowa's defense held the Huskies to just 21 yards rushing. The Hawkeyes won, 16â3, and ended the four-game losing streak that comprised the final four games of Iowa's [[2006 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|2006 season]].{{cite web|title = Iowa 16, Northern Illinois 3|url = http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200709010042|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = 2007-09-01|accessdate = 2007-12-15}} The next week, Iowa defeated Syracuse in the Hawkeyes' home opener, 35â0. Jake Christensen threw for 278 yards and four [[touchdown]]s as the Hawkeye defense held the Orange to just five [[Down (American football)|first downs]] and 103 yards of total offense in Syracuse's worst defeat since a 51â14 loss to [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]] in the 2004 [[Champs Sports Bowl]].{{cite web|title = Iowa 35, Syracuse 0|url = http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200709080028|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = 2007-09-09|accessdate = 2008-01-19}} Iowa took a quick 28â0 lead with 9:55 left in the second quarter, and the Hawkeye defense sacked Syracuse six times while holding the Orange to 24 rushing yards.{{cite web|title = Blown away: Iowa rolls over Syracuse with dominating first half|url = http://media.www.dailyorange.com/media/storage/paper522/news/2007/09/07/Sports/Fb.Blown.Away.Iowa.Rolls.Over.Syracuse.With.Dominating.First.Half-2956927.shtml|publisher = The Daily Orange|date = |accessdate = 2008-01-24}} Following the first two games â which saw the Iowa defense give up only three points â the Hawkeyes traveled to [[Ames, Iowa|Ames]], [[Iowa]], to play 0â2 [[Iowa State Cyclones football|Iowa State]] on September 15. The Cyclones began the season with losses to [[Kent State Golden Flashes#Football|Kent State]] and [[Northern Iowa Panthers#Football|Northern Iowa]], but had won six out of the last nine games against the Hawkeyes, including three of the last four played at [[Jack Trice Stadium]]. Iowa fell behind by 12 at [[half-time]], and lost, 15â13, starting yet another four-game losing streak. [[Placekicker]] Bret Culbertson scored all of Iowa State's points on five [[Field goal (football)|field goals]], the last coming with one second remaining.{{cite web|title = Iowa State's game-winning kick caps win over Iowa|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=272580066|publisher = ESPN|date = 2007-09-15|accessdate = 2008-01-19}} [[File:Iowa takes the field at PSU.jpg|thumb|left|Iowa takes the field on October 6, 2007, against [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]].]] Following a 20-point loss at [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] on October 6,{{cite news|title = Lions maul hapless Hawkeyes; Penn State 27, Iowa 7|url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4155/is_20071007/ai_n21034835|publisher = Chicago Sun-Times|date = 2007-10-07|accessdate = 2007-12-15}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} which was preceded by losses to [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]] and [[Indiana Hoosiers football|Indiana]], the Hawkeyes returned to Kinnick Stadium for a game against [[Illinois Fighting Illini football|Illinois]], who was coming into the game after home victories over Penn State and Wisconsin.{{cite web|title = Illinois Fighting Illini Schedule - 2007|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/teams/schedule?teamId=356|publisher = ESPN|date = |accessdate = 2008-01-19}} Christensen threw for 182 yards and the game's only touchdown â a 20-yard pass to Brandon Myers in the third quarter which gave the Hawkeyes a 10â6 lead. However, it appeared that Illinois had taken a 12â10 lead on an 83-yard Eddie McGee touchdown pass midway through the fourth quarter, but it was called back due to a [[American football#Penalties|penalty]]. The Illini were forced to [[Punt (football)|punt]], but got the ball back with 2:28 remaining. McGee threw passes of 28 and 24 yards to [[Arrelious Benn]], putting the Illini at the Iowa 12-yard line. However, Brett Greenwood [[interception|intercepted]] a McGee pass at the goal-line, sealing the win and snapping an eight-game Big Ten losing streak for Iowa heading into a road game at Purdue.{{cite web|title = Christensen, Young help Iowa snap eight-game Big Ten skid|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=272862294|publisher = ESPN|date = 2007-10-13|accessdate = 2008-01-19}}{{cite news|title = Mild shock, bad burn; Iowa 10, Illinois 6: Quarterback change no|url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4155/is_20071014/ai_n21047915|publisher = Chicago Sun-Times|date = 2007-10-14|accessdate = 2007-12-15}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} But Iowa lost to the Boilermakers a week later, 31â6, to put the Hawkeyes' record at 3â5 with only four games remaining. [[Curtis Painter]] threw for 315 yards and three touchdowns for Purdue, who had lost to the Hawkeyes, 47â17, only a year earlier.{{cite web|title = Purdue 31, Iowa 6|url = http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200710200035|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = 2007-10-20|accessdate = 2007-12-15}} In Iowa's next game against Michigan State, the Hawkeyes entered half-time down by 14 points only to take a 20â17 lead with 10:05 remaining in regulation. The game was destined for [[Overtime (sports)|overtime]] when Michigan State's [[Brett Swenson]] hit a field goal with four seconds remaining, and the Spartans quickly garnered a seven-point lead following a Jehuu Caulcrick touchdown in the first overtime. Down by a touchdown, Christensen found [[wide receiver]] Paul Chaney for a 23-yard touchdown pass and following the [[extra point]], the game headed to double overtime. Iowa had the ball first and scored on a Jevon Pugh one-yard run, giving the Hawkeyes their own seven-point lead. However, the Spartans were unable to score and Iowa won, 34â27. The win was Iowa's first overtime victory in Kinnick Stadium history.{{cite news|title = Michigan State Spartans vs. Iowa Hawkeyes|url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/ncaa/boxscores/2007/10/27/36131_boxscore.html|publisher = SI.com|date = 2007-10-30|accessdate = 2007-12-09}}{{cite news|title = Subs' subs subdue Spartans; Iowa 34, Michigan State 27|url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4155/is_20071028/ai_n21075085|publisher = Chicago Sun-Times|date = 2007-10-28|accessdate = 2007-12-13}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} [[File:Iowa vs. Western Michigan 2007.jpg|thumb|right|Iowa's offense sets up against [[Western Michigan Broncos football|Western Michigan]]'s defense on November 17, 2007.]] On November 3, Iowa defeated [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]], 28â17, after trailing, 14â0, in the first quarter. The Wildcats took a 17â14 on a third quarter field goal after the Hawkeyes tied the game at 14, but Sims ran for two fourth quarter touchdowns to seal the Iowa victory. Christensen threw for 299 yards for Iowa, who came back from a 14-point deficit in the second straight game.{{cite web|title = Christensen airs it out, Sims scores twice in Iowa's 28-17 win over Northwestern|url = http://www.bigtennetwork.com/news/article.asp?STORY_ID=7341|publisher = Big Ten Network|date = 2007-11-03|accessdate = 2007-12-15|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071106100210/http://www.bigtennetwork.com/news/article.asp?STORY_ID=7341 |archivedate = November 06, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Later, on November 10, Iowa defeated Minnesota, 21â16, to reclaim the [[Floyd of Rosedale]] trophy. With one home game remaining against [[Western Michigan Broncos football|Western Michigan]], Iowa held a three-game winning streak and a 6â5 overall record. But the Hawkeyes lost to the Broncos, 28â19, and gave up 489 yards in the process. Western Michigan took a 19â0 second quarter lead before Iowa scored 13 straight points to make it a six-point game. But the Hawks would get no closer and eventually lost by nine.{{cite web|title = W. Michigan 28, Iowa 19|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273212294|publisher = ESPN|date = 2007-11-17|accessdate = 2008-01-19}} Soon thereafter, Iowa was not selected for a bowl game, ending a six-year streak in which the Hawkeyes played in a bowl and rumors about the firing of Kirk Ferentz were rampant.{{cite web|title = College football: Hawks fail to land bowl bid|url = http://www.wcfcourier.com/articles/2007/12/03/sports/local/doc47542585bea91020676413.txt|publisher = WCF Courier|date = 2007-12-03|accessdate = 2007-12-15}} ===Coaching rumors=== Following Michigan's loss to Appalachian State, rumors about the possibility of Ferentz becoming Michigan's head coach began to circulate.{{cite web|title = Iowa's Kirk Ferentz offered Michigan job?|url = http://www.fanblogs.com/michigan/007325.php|publisher = Fanblogs.com|date = 2007-11-26|accessdate = 2007-12-15}}{{cite web|title = Say Hello To My Little Ferentz|url = http://mgoblog.blogspot.com/2007/11/say-hello-to-my-little-ferentz.html|publisher = MGoBlog|date = 2007-11-25|accessdate = 2007-12-15}} [[LSU Tigers football|LSU]] coach [[Les Miles]] was widely believed to be Michigan's top choice for the job,{{cite web|title = Kirk Ferentz to Michigan? Really?|url = http://sports.aol.com/fanhouse/2007/11/23/kirk-ferentz-to-michigan-really/|publisher = FanHouse|date = 2007-11-23|accessdate = 2007-12-16}} but any chance of that happening likely ended when LSU extended Miles' contract through 2012.{{cite web|title = LSU extends Miles' contract through '12|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3144459|publisher = ESPN|date = 2007-12-06|accessdate = 2007-12-16}} Ferentz's relationship with Michigan president [[Mary Sue Coleman]] may have contributed to the rumor, as Coleman was the president at Iowa when Ferentz was hired. However, indications that the rumor was false were revealed when Iowa's sports information director, Phil Haddy, reported that Michigan had not asked for permission to talk with Ferentz.{{cite web|title = Iowa: No permission granted to talk with Ferentz|url = http://www.mlive.com/wolverines/index.ssf/2007/11/iowa_no_permission_granted_to.html|publisher = MLive.com|date = 2007-11-26|accessdate = 2007-12-16}} It was a point reiterated by [[Gary Barta]], Iowa's [[athletic director]].{{cite web|title = Ferentz-Michigan link befuddles Barta|url = http://www.gazetteonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071119/SPORTS/71119014/1008/sports|publisher = Cedar Rapids Gazette|date = 2007-11-19|accessdate = 2007-12-15}}{{cite web|title = Barta: No schools have contacted UI about Ferentz|url = http://www.desmoinesregister.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071126/SPORTS020502/71126024|publisher = Des Moines Register|date = 2007-11-26|accessdate = 2007-12-16}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Ferentz's contract has a clause requiring him to contact Barta when talking to other schools, which indicates that he was not a candidate to become Michigan's next head coach. On December 16, West Virginia's [[Rich Rodriguez]] was hired as Carr's successor at Michigan.{{cite news|title = Michigan hires WVU's Rodriguez|url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/football/ncaa/specials/bowls/2007/12/16/michigan.rodriguez.ap/index.html|publisher = SI.com|date = 2007-12-16|accessdate = 2007-12-16 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071218163314/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/football/ncaa/specials/bowls/2007/12/16/michigan.rodriguez.ap/index.html |archivedate = 2007-12-18}} Soon thereafter, Ferentz was once again rumored for a coaching job, this time for the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. Ferentz was an assistant head coach at Baltimore for six years,{{cite web|title = Hawkeyes Look to 2008|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/121807aab.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = 2007-12-18|accessdate = 2007-12-19}} and became a "respected assistant" in his time there. However, when asked about the Baltimore job, Ferentz said, "I've got a great job here, and with that being said, I'm sure Baltimore will get a top-notch coach." Ferentz also cited wanting to see his son James â who is slated to be a [[First year|freshman]] at Iowa in 2008 â play every weekend.{{cite web|title = Ferentz indicates he'll stay at Iowa|url = http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/football/bal-sp.ferentz05jan05,0,7588656.story|publisher = Baltimore Sun|date = 2008-01-05|accessdate = 2008-01-20|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20110522122032/http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/football/bal-sp.ferentz05jan05,0,7588656.story |archivedate = May 22, 2011|deadurl=yes}} The Ravens eventually hired [[Philadelphia Eagles]] secondary coach [[John Harbaugh]] on January 18, 2008.{{cite web|title = Ravens hire Harbaugh as coach|url = http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/football/bal-harbaugh118,0,5839718.story?coll=sns-ap-entertainment-headlines|publisher = Baltimore Sun|date = 2008-01-18|accessdate = 2008-01-24|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20110522122112/http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/football/bal-harbaugh118,0,5839718.story?coll=sns-ap-entertainment-headlines |archivedate = May 22, 2011|deadurl=yes}} ===Recruiting class=== The Hawkeyes had 24 verbal commitments for the 2008 recruiting class. One of the players, Nate Guillory, is a [[junior college]] recruit. The other 23 players are all [[high school]] [[Twelfth grade|seniors]]. James Ferentz, Kirk's son, is among the players committed to play for Iowa in 2008.{{cite web|title = Iowa Hawkeyes 2008 Commits|url = http://iowa.scout.com/a.z?s=8&p=9&c=8&yr=2008|publisher = Scout.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-12-21}}{{cite web|title = Iowa Commit List for 2008|url = http://iowa.rivals.com/commitlist.asp|publisher = Rivals.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-12-21}} ==Schedule== {{See also|2008 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings}} The Hawkeyes will open the 2008 season with three home games against {{cfb link|year=2008|team=Maine Black Bears|title=Maine}}, [[2008 FIU Golden Panthers football team|Florida International]], and Iowa State, followed by a road game versus Pittsburgh.{{cite web|title = Future Schedules|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/future-schedules.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-12-09}} The game will mark the first of four meetings between Pittsburgh and Iowa. The teams will meet in Iowa City in 2011 and 2015, and in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]] in 2016.{{cite web|title = Pitt football reveals schedule|url = http://media.www.pittnews.com/media/storage/paper879/news/2005/07/13/SportsonlineExtra/Pitt-Football.Reveals.Schedule-1786570.shtml|publisher = The Pitt News|date = 2005-07-13|accessdate = 2007-12-13|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080120142832/http://media.www.pittnews.com/media/storage/paper879/news/2005/07/13/SportsonlineExtra/Pitt-Football.Reveals.Schedule-1786570.shtml |archivedate = January 20, 2008|deadurl=yes}} Pitt closed the 2007 season with an upset victory over second-ranked [[2007 West Virginia Mountaineers football team|West Virginia]]. Had the Mountaineers won, they would have likely played in the [[2008 BCS National Championship Game|national championship game]].{{cite web|title = Pitt throws curveball at BCS with win over No. 2 WVU|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273350277|publisher = ESPN|date = 2007-12-01|accessdate = 2007-12-27}} Following the conclusion of the non-conference portion of their schedule, the Hawkeyes will begin Big Ten play with a home game against Northwestern, and will open October with road games against Michigan State and Indiana. Iowa was 1â1 against the Spartans and Hoosiers in 2007, winning, 34â27, over MSU while losing, 38â20, to IU. Following the two road games, Iowa will play at home against Wisconsin. Iowa lost, 17â13, to the Badgers in 2007. Following a bye week, the Hawkeyes will play at Illinois, in what will be Iowa's third road game in five weeks. However, Iowa follows this with two home games, against Penn State and Purdue. Iowa lost to both teams in 2007 by 20 points or more.{{cite news|title = Iowa Hawkeyes 2007 Schedule and Results|url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/ncaa/schedules/team/2007/iowa/index.html|publisher = SI.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-12-13}} A week following the Hawkeyes' final home game against Purdue, Iowa will play Minnesota in the Gophers' home finale.{{cite web|title = Minnesota Golden Gophers Football - 2008 Schedule|url = http://www.gophersports.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=38609&SPID=3280&DB_OEM_ID=8400&KEY=&Q_SEASON=2008|publisher = GopherSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-12-09}} {{dead link|date=September 2011}} Minnesota will look to take back the Floyd of Rosedale trophy a year after Iowa won it for the sixth time in seven years.{{cite web|title = Iowa 21, Minnesota 16|url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273142294|publisher = ESPN|date = 2007-11-10|accessdate = 2007-12-27}} The game will likely also be Minnesota's last at the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]].Minnesota plans to begin playing football at [[TCF Bank Stadium]] in 2009. Therefore, the final home game at the Metrodome will take place on November 22, 2008, against Iowa. Two of Iowa's games â vs. Northwestern and at Michigan State â have been scheduled for 11:05 a.m. starts.{{cite web|title = Two Iowa Football Game Times Announced|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/051208aaa.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = 2008-05-12|accessdate = 2008-05-12}} The season finale against Minnesota has been set for a 6:00 p.m. start time.{{cite web|title = Iowa-Minnesota Football Game Time Set|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/051308aaa.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = 2008-05-13|accessdate = 2008-05-13}} {{CFB Schedule Start|time=|rank=|ranklink=|rankyear=2008|attend=yes|tv=}} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = August 30 | time = 11:00 a.m. | w/l = w | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | away = | neutral = | rank = | opponent = {{cfb link|year=2008|team=Maine Black Bears|title=Maine}} | opprank = | site_stadium = [[Kinnick Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Iowa City, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania|PA]] | gamename = | tv = [[ESPN2]] | score = 21â20 | overtime = | attend = 50,321 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = September 27 | time = 11:05 a.m. | w/l = City, IA | gamename = | tv = [[ESPN Classic]] | score = 22â17 | overtime = | attend = 70,585 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = October 4 | time = 11:05 a.m. | w/l = l | nonconf = | homecoming = | Humphrey Metrodome]] | site_cityst = [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota|MN]] | gamename = [[Floyd of Rosedale|Battle for the Floyd of Rosedale]] | tv = BTN | score = 55-0 | overtime = | attend = 64,071 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = [[January 1|January 1*]] | time = 10:00 a.m. | w/l = w | nonconf = | homecoming = | away = | neutral = yes | rank = | opponent = [[2008 South Carolina Gamecocks football team|South Carolina]] | opprank = | site_stadium = [[Raymond James Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], [[Florida|FL]] | gamename = [[2009 Outback Bowl|Outback Bowl]] | tv = ESPN | score = 31-10 | overtime = | attend = 55,117 }} {{CFB Schedule End|timezone=[[Central Time]]}} ==Personnel== ===Coaches=== {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left:1em" |- ! colspan="8" style="background:#000; color:Gold; text-align:center;"|'''2008 Iowa Hawkeyes football coaches''' |- |valign="top"| | style="font-size:95%; vertical-align:top;"| * Head Coach - [[Kirk Ferentz]] * Strength and Conditioning - Chris Doyle '''Offensive Coaches''' * Offensive Coordinator and Quarterbacks - [[Ken O'Keefe]] * Running Backs and Special teams - Lester Erb * Wide receivers and Tight ends - Erik Campbell * Offensive Line - Reese Morgan * Recruiting and linebackers assistant - Eric Johnson '''Defensive Coaches''' * Defensive Coordinator and Linebackers - Norm Parker * Defensive Backs - Phil Parker * Defensive Line - Rick Kaczenski * Outside Linebackers and Special teams - Darrell Wilson
---- Source: [http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/iowa-m-footbl-mtt.html#coaches HawkeyeSports.com] |} Kirk Ferentz will be in his tenth season as head coach at Iowa in 2008, and he has a 61â49 record entering the season. Ferentz came to Iowa in 1999, following an assistant coaching job for the [[Baltimore Ravens]] and a heading coaching job at Maine. Earlier in his career, Ferentz was an assistant coach under [[Hayden Fry]] at Iowa. From 1981â1989, Ferentz was Iowa's offensive line coach. From there, Ferentz took the heading coaching position at Maine, and followed that by taking an assistant position in Baltimore. He was named Iowa's 25th head football coach on December 2, 1998. Norm Parker, Iowa's [[defensive coordinator]], will also be in his tenth year at Iowa.{{cite web|title = Norm Parker|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/parker_norm00.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2008-01-02}} The same can also be said for [[Ken O'Keefe]], Iowa's [[offensive coordinator]].{{cite web|title = Ken O'Keefe|url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/okeefe_ken00.html|publisher = HawkeyeSports.com|date = |accessdate = 2008-01-02}} Under Parker, Iowa's rushing defense has nationally ranked in the top 10 in three seasons. Parker has also coached several [[linebacker]]s now playing in the [[NFL]], including [[Chad Greenway]], [[Abdul Hodge]], and [[LeVar Woods]]. Before coming to Iowa, Parker coached 12 seasons at Michigan State, five at Minnesota, and three at Illinois. Under O'Keefe, Iowa has had the top scoring offense in the Big Ten twice, in 2001 and 2002, and 14 offensive players coached by O'Keefe have been [[NFL Draft|drafted]] into the NFL. Before coaching at Iowa, O'Keefe was the head coach at [[Allegheny College]], where he won a [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] national title in 1990. He was also head coach at [[Fordham University]] for one year before coming to Iowa. ===Players=== Returning for the Hawkeyes in 2008 are nine starters on offense, and as many as 18 total starters could be back for Iowa. Senior running back Young is gone, along with fellow running back Damian Sims and [[Fullback (American football)|fullback]] Tom Busch. The rest of the offense, including the [[offensive line]] and [[wide receiver]] positions, are intact going into 2008. On the defense, up to seven starters may return, but the Hawkeyes lose linebackers [[Mike Klinkenborg]] and Mike Humpal along with [[defensive end]]s [[Kenny Iwebema]] and [[Bryan Mattison]]. [[Cornerback]]s [[Adam Shada]] and [[Charles Godfrey (American football)|Charles Godfrey]] are also done with their playing days at Iowa. Godfrey, who completed 2007 with five [[interception]]s,{{cite news|title = #13 Charles Godfrey|url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/ncaa/players/21612/index.html|publisher = SI.com|date = |accessdate = 2008-01-05}} was regarded as a possible third- to sixth-round draft pick in the [[2008 NFL Draft]] before being picked in the third-round.{{cite web|title = Charles Godfrey, CB, Iowa|url = http://www.nfldraftscout.com/ratings/profile.php?pyid=33090|publisher = NFL Draft Scout|date = |accessdate = 2008-01-05}}{{cite web|title = 2008 NFL Draft: Day Two Ball-Hawking DBs|url = http://profootballexperts.scout.com/2/699262.html|publisher = Scout.com|author = Chris Steuber|date = 2007-11-07|accessdate = 2008-01-05}} Another Iowa player, Devan Moylan, is seeking for another year after missing most of 2007 with an injury. Returnees on offense include [[Jake Christensen]], who succeeded [[Drew Tate]] at the [[quarterback]] position. Christensen threw for 2,269 yards and 17 [[touchdown]]s in his [[sophomore]] season, while throwing only six interceptions. Also returning are 11 [[true freshman|true freshmen]] and 20 [[Redshirt (college sports)|redshirt freshmen]] who saw playing time in 2007. With 31 total freshmen receiving playing time, the Hawkeyes ranked third in the country in that category, behind [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina]] and [[2008 Florida Gators football team|Florida]], who played 38 and 33 freshmen respectively. ==Season== ===Maine=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Black Bears |R1= 0 |R2= 3 |R3= 0 |R4= 0 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1= 14 |H2= 8 |H3= 3 |H4=
